definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) ( of a wheel, sled runner, or vehicle tracks ) To slide along the ground, without the rotary motion that wheels or tracks would normally have.
( intransitive ) To slide in an uncontrolled manner as in a car with the brakes applied too hard, the wheels sliding with limited spinning.
examples: They skidded around the corner and accelerated up the street.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , transitive , aviation ) To operate an aircraft in a banked sideslip with the nose yawed towards the low wing.
examples: Don't use excessive rudder when turning, especially at low airspeed, as this causes your plane to skid through the turn, which can cause you to very rapidly enter a spin if the inner wing stalls.
Because of the jammed ailerons, the pilot had to use careful rudder inputs to skid his plane in order to turn it so he could get lined up with the runway.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To protect or support with a skid or skids.
( transitive ) To cause to move on skids.
( transitive ) To check or halt (wagon wheels, etc.) with a skid.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) ( of a wheel, sled runner, or vehicle tracks ) To slide along the ground, without the rotary motion that wheels or tracks would normally have.

( intransitive , transitive , aviation ) To operate an aircraft in a banked sideslip with the nose yawed towards the low wing.
( transitive ) To protect or support with a skid or skids.
( transitive ) To cause to move on skids.
( transitive ) To check or halt (wagon wheels, etc.) with a skid.

definitions.definition: To steal or copy, especially computer code.

main_definition: ( Internet slang ) To steal or copy, especially computer code.
